The gravitational constant, also identified as the 'universal gravitational constant', remains the same throughout the universe regardless of the mass / size of the object.

I believe it's because we are deciding which object's gravitional field we are observing. If we were observing m2 for example, we would cancel that out. In this case, we are observing the earth so we cancel out the mass of the earth to remove it on both sides of the equation. If we were observing the moon, we would cancel out the mass of the moon.  Please feel free to correct me as this is just an inference from the video and is not backed up by any studies whatsoever.
I believe it could be any one of the two 'm' — since it's done merely for the derivation of a simplified equation here.
They both mean the same thing, just seen from different perspectives. From F=ma, 1 N = 1 kgms^-2. So N/kg can be written as (kgms^-2)/kg and the kg cancels out to give ms^-2.
It is the same thing because N=kg/ms^2 so N/kg, the kg will cancel
